--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Mark Ahlstrom <lists@d...> wrote:
> It's been a long while since I posted trolling for masters thesis 
> ideas, and this is both an update and a request for some 
advice/sample 
> code.
> 
> In short, I am examining the differences between recurrent, fixed 
> weight networks and networks with dynamic synapses in an adaptive 
> control system.  This follows one of Kens papers, but extends it 
into 
> more complex networks.  The general problem area is, as suggested 
> previously, aircraft control.  The idea is to maintain level, 
constant 
> speed flight of the aircraft as environmental and/or aircraft 
> characteristics change.  This could mean the engine losing power, 
a 
> wing losing lift or control ability, wind changes, etc. Regarding 
this, 
> Im looking for any recommendations for papers to look at, and 
ideas on 
> what kinds of things to toss into the experimental environment.  
The 
> tentative plan now is to run the aircraft through a number of 
random 
> environments with different changes or combinations of changes, 
and 
> calculate fitness based off of a deviation from the original path 
as 
> compared to the deviation of an aircraft that's done nothing.
> 
> The area I could use some help in is with some modifications to 
the 
> original neat code.  Since the aircraft control is fairly complex, 
I've 
> been working at making neat parallel to cut down the time it takes 
to 
> run all this.  Mostly, since this is running on an openmosix 
cluster, 
> this means forking complex procedures that are called from inside 
a 
> loop.  Any other potential locations for speedups?  I've also been 
> re-implementing the front end in KDE, since that's usually the 
> environment Im working under.  From those who have done re-writes 
of 
> neat before, is there anything in particular I should be 
especially 
> careful of?  Now, where I need help is with implementing plastic 
> synapses.  Since I will be comparing this with Ken's original 
results, 
> I'd like to implement them in a manner similar to what Ken had for 
his 
> food foraging experiments.  A rough outline of the implementation, 
or 
> better yet, source code, would be appreciated.
> 

Hi Mark, just to make sure I understand, you are using my NEAT code 
right?  

One really big area that is easy to parallelize is individual 
evaluations.  If each individual in the population can be evaluated 
individually, then you can parallelize as many evaluations as you 
have processors.  In that case, you get an n-times speedup in 
evaluation where n is the # processors, and I am betting that in 
your domain evaluation is by far taking up most of the processing 
(as opposed to e.g. NEAT genetic operations). 

I will try to put together a tar of my adaptive NEAT files in the 
next few days.  I can't provide experimental control code (it's far 
too complicated and undocumented) but I can provide the genetics.* 
and networks.* files that implement adaptive synapses.  However, if 
you are using someone else's NEAT code this obviously won't help so 
let me know if I am right that you are using my code.

ken
